Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "MAS 2.5.2 - Pointer Cancellation" (#7535) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "Implement WCAG 2.1" (#7534) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
There are new accessibility standards that we need to abide by. We need to analyze our site to determine if there are any issues with our analysis of them.

Note that I have not included the following standards, which do not apply to us:
- MAS 2.1.4: Character Key Shortcuts
- MAS 2.5.1: Pointer Gestures
- MAS 2.5.2: Pointer Cancellation
- MAS 2.5.4: Motion Actuation

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "MAS 1.4.12 Text spacing" (#7529) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "MAS 1.4.11 - Non-text contrast" (#7528) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "[Azure Search] Documents with null isExcludedByDefault are excluded from default search" (#7506) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This is not a big deal right now since the default search is dominated by documents initialized by `Db2AzureSearch`, but theoretically a new package ID can could be introduced by `Catalog2AzureSearch` that has a null `isExcludedByDefault` and will therefore never appear in the default search results.

`Db2AzureSearch` is the only job that sets `isExcludedByDefault` so package IDs introduced (or relisted) after the index rebuild will never appear in the default search because the Azure Search services looks for `isExcludedByDefault eq false`. We can easily fix this by switching to `isExcludedByDefault ne true` to include both the `false` and the `null` case.

This can easily be seen here:
https://azuresearch-usnc.dev.nugettest.org/search/query?sortBy=created-desc

Notice the newest packages is on 2019-09-03. Whereas the newest is on 2019-09-05 here:
https://azuresearch-usnc.dev.nugettest.org/search/query?sortBy=created-desc&q=e2e

/cc @shishirx34

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add organization membership and transform actions use POST" (#7522) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
The following actions are no longer performed with action links from emails. Instead the email links redirect to a web page where the user can click a form button (which does a POST) that does the same action as before.

- Accept organization migration request
  - Available to recipient
- Reject organization migration request
  - Available to recipient
- Cancel organization migration request
  - Available to sender
- Accept organization membership request
  - Available to recipient
- Reject organization membership request
  - Available to recipient

To make this work for cancelling migration requests, I had to modify the UI since there was no part of the website that allowed the user to cancel a migration.

I also cleaned up the obfuscator tests since I wanted to be sure my new redirect endpoints were properly obfuscating usernames and tokens.

I also added a better error message for the case when a user starts an organization migration and they log in as the wrong user during the migration flow. Previously it just showed a generic failure message.

Address https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/2679

# Screenshots

## Cancel migration

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/64496836-f1adc700-d25d-11e9-9f75-d4fd548e3e97.png)

## Accept or reject migration

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/64496897-7f89b200-d25e-11e9-8abf-135de020b8fa.png)

## Accept or reject membership

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/64496913-ae078d00-d25e-11e9-8c6e-8713d3a9622e.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Project Dependencies of ProjectReferences marked as PrivateAssets should not be included in the lock file up to date check" (#8565) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
[8493.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/3593090/8493.zip)

Extract the above project, run dotnet restore --locked-mode

Motivation from https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8493. 

Issue being hit by @bddckr 

fyi @tebeco Not your specific issue, but one that the discussion produced. 

I want to keep this issue focused to the problem at hand. 

Specifically refer to https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8493#issuecomment-526537492. 

Note that this has never worked correctly, so not a regression (in 4.9, it simply didn't validate it)

The fix is: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/638f34578d2221abc1259286ce2d4c132600cea7/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.ProjectModel/ProjectLockFile/PackagesLockFileUtilities.cs#L168

We should strip out the PrivateAssets=All project references from `p2pSpecProjectRestoreMetadataFrameworkInfo.ProjectReferences`. 

fyi @rrelyea

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Solution PM UI - Deprecation warning icon has issues" (#8516) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2878341/63895701-bc26f500-c9a4-11e9-91c3-08f27f91c915.png)


1. Create a solution with 1 project.
1. Install a deprecated package.
1. Open the solution level PM UI
1. Go to the installed tab.

You will see that the installed label has a warning icon, but in the packages list you cannot distinguish visually which package is deprecated. This is an issue. 

Note that this is not an issue on the project level PM UI. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2878341/63895798-0c9e5280-c9a5-11e9-9eef-2024bebb9fe5.png)

This leads to an underwhelming experience, that I believe we should fix before shipping. 

//cc @rrelyea @anangaur @xavierdecoster @scottbommarito @NuGet/nuget-client

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Deprecation info is not visible, by default, on installed tab" (#8541) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Feature: Deprecation

The idea of the feature on VS was to show the deprecation info as warning ‚ö†Ô∏è on the INSTALLED tab. Clicking on this tab leads to the packages listed and are deprecated using the warning ‚ö†Ô∏è icon on package‚Äôs installed version. Clicking on this reveals the warning ‚ö†Ô∏è icon and deprecation info on the details pane. Essentially the warning ‚ö†Ô∏è icons leads to the issue details.

This doesn‚Äôt happen today because the installed tab shows the package details of the latest version by default and not if the one that‚Äôs installed.

Proposed fix, reviewed by UX:
* There is no need to show both the installed  version and the latest version on the installed tab. We can show just the one installed:

Version: \<Installed version in the drop down> UnistallButton

Will update the proposed UX soon.

Events.RelatedBody:

| Command | Status | Notes |

| remove | | |

| consolidate --dry-run | | |

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "How to suppress error NU1202 'Package is not compatible with netcoreapp'" (#8560) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Please read the following information before posting the issue.

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): dotnet.exe 

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 2.8.7.0 on Linux

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 2.2.107

VS version (if appropriate): N/A

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a netcoreapp2.2 reference netframework472 package. If you have permissions, you can use my app 

2. Try to run dotnet restore on Linux 


Here's the thing. I'm getting *warning* NU1701 when restoring this on Windows, and I am able to easily suppress it. I'm getting *error* NU1202 for the same exact package reference when trying to restore that project on Linux, and I can't figure out a way to suppress that error.

I know the reference netframework472 code runs fine on netcore, including on Linux, as I tested it without using <PackageReference ...> first. So the issue here really is "how do I suppress that error?". Also, why am I getting a different error on linux than warning on Windows for the same exact package? 

Here's my sample package reference

`<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.VisualStudio.Language.StandardClassification" Version="$(CoreEditorAssemblyVersion)" NoWarn="NU1701" />`

BTW, I'm MSFT employee, alias alexgav, so feel free to ping me internally.

Thanks,
Alex

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "VSLangProj/PackageReferences, Package Restore with .NET Core 3.0 and FrameworkReferences" (#8563) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
**Visual Studio project system and Framework References for NuGet client**

I've updated to using Visual Studio 2019 16.3 Preview 3 with .NET Core Preview 9. As a third-party language vendor I have an implementation of VSLangProj150/PackageReferences. It is unclear to me whether the implementation of get_InstalledPackages should include the new FrameworkReference element or not.

Before Preview 9 I could return the implicit Microsoft.NETCore.App package. However, after installing preview 9 I get an error when executing a NuGet restore (through the VS interface, not from MSBuild):

... (1,1-1) : error NU1102 : Unable to find package Microsoft.NETCore.App with version (>= 3.0.0-preview9-19423-09)
... (1,1-1) : error NU1102 : - Found 74 version(s) in nuget.org [ Nearest version: 3.0.0-preview8-28405-07 ]
... : error NU1102 : - Found 0 version(s) in Microsoft Visual Studio Offline Packages

Can someone give guidance or clarity about how a project system should return Framework References to NuGet client in this scenario? I can just stop returning this and the problem goes away, but I assume at some point there will be third party Framework References that would need to be restored.


OS version:
Windows 10 1903

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Test Failure]The ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button is still clickable in ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab on PM UI when the package with latest version has been installed" (#8562) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
VS Version: D16.3 29307.09
NuGet Version: Release-5.3.x\5.3.0.6231
OS Version: Windows-10-Enterprise-19H1-04-05-2019.
## Detailed repro steps 
1. Launch Visual Studio 2019.
2. Create a C# Console Application (.Net Core) project and open PM UI in Solution Explorer window.
3. Install a package (e.g. Newtonsoft.json) with latest version into the project.
## Expected
The ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button should be gray in browse tab on PM UI right panel as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/64520707-48340780-d329-11e9-8b8a-f26ba4221b4f.png)
## Actual
The ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button still is clickable in ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab on PM UI when the package with latest version has been installed as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/64520762-5f72f500-d329-11e9-9407-a0aa0cbb4d97.png)
## Notes
1. The issue does not repro on D16.3\29305.141 + NuGet Client Release-5.3.x\5.3.0.6224.
2. When switching to the ‚ÄúInstalled‚Äù tab, the ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button is gray, and then switch to the ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab, the ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button turns gray.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Rerunning 'dotnet add package ...' creates duplicate in non-SDK" (#8561) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (dotnet.exe):

dotnet.exe --version:
Both 2.2.103 and 3.0.100-preview9-014004

OS version:
win10 1903

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:
Works in SDK projects and through Rider and VS UI

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. For a non-SDK project using PackageReferences and containing
`<PackageReference Include="Newtonsoft.Json" Version="11.0.1" />`

2. Run `dotnet add package Newtonsoft.Json` to update to 12.0.2

3.  Project now contains a new entry instead of updating the reference
```
    <PackageReference Include="Newtonsoft.Json" Version="11.0.1" />
    <PackageReference Include="Newtonsoft.Json" Version="12.0.2" />
```
4. Run `dotnet add package Newtonsoft.Json` again, another entry is added
```
    <PackageReference Include="Newtonsoft.Json" Version="11.0.1" />
    <PackageReference Include="Newtonsoft.Json" Version="12.0.2" />
    <PackageReference Include="Newtonsoft.Json" Version="12.0.2" />
```

## Other suggested things

### Sample non-SDK Project
[ClassLibrary1.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/3588111/ClassLibrary1.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Using OData to query NuGet.org repository is being deprecated" (#37) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We introduced `V3 APIs` in early 2016. We have made continuous investments to make it more reliable, performant and secure. Going forward, we plan to bring all new features and improvements only to the newer `V3 APIs`. As part of this strategy, we are deprecating the usage of `OData` queries. Subsequently, we plan to **disable the `OData` queries starting Feb 5th, 2020**.

**Call to Action: Transition to V3 APIs**

Here are some resources to help you with the migration:
* [NuGet Server `V3 APIs` reference](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/switching-from-wcf-odata-to-web-api/)
* [Guide to transition from NuGet `V2 API` to `V3 API`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/guides/api/query-for-all-published-packages). 
* [Blog post: Switching from WCF OData to Web API](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/switching-from-wcf-odata-to-web-api/)

If you need further help in moving your use case to `V3 APIs`, do reach out to us at [support@nuget.org](mailto:support@nuget.org).

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Replace reference to codeplex issue numer 3072" (#36) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
This is copy of codeplex issue number 3072 as it is referenced inside code. I should do a PR shortly to address this one.

The place where it is referenced is RuntimeHelper.cs:150


---

We're hitting an issue with Microsoft.Bcl package where NuGet is adding a binding redirect for a binary that is considered part of the framework, this causes the application to crash because the binding redirect refers to assembly version that is not available at runtime.

@Repro:

1. Create a new Console Application targeting 4.5
2. Create a new Portable Library targeting .NET Framework 4.5, Silverlight 4, Windows Phone 7.5 and .NET for Windows Store apps
3. Add a reference to the portable library from the Console Application
4. Install the Microsoft.Bcl package (1.0.16-rc) to both projects

@Expected: No binding redirect for System.Runtime in the .NET Framework 4.5 project because a ___later version___ is part of the target framework (see C:\Program Files (x86)\Reference Assemblies\Microsoft\Framework\.NETFramework\v4.5\RedistList\FrameworkList.xml)
@Actual: Binding redirect

<dependentAssembly>
<assemblyIdentity name="System.Runtime" publicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" culture="neutral" />
<bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-1.5.11.0" newVersion="1.5.11.0" />
</dependentAssembly>


You can use the IVsFrameworkMultiTargeting to determine if a given assembly version is available as part of a given target framework.
Make sure when you fix this, that you only skip the binding redirect if ___a later or same version___ is available in the framework.  
2013-02-22

---

We'll do this in 2.4 release.  
2013-02-26

---

Is IVsFrameworkMultiTargeting.IsReferenceableInTargetFx the method I need to call? What should I pass to pwszAssemblySpec?  
2013-06-08

---

It's the full name of the assembly (mscorlib, Version=[version], PublicKeyToken=[token], Culture=[culture]). It can either contain all the information (key, version, etc), or just the simple name ("mscorlib")  
2013-06-10

---

So look like I can only check for the same version of the target framework. Can't check for a later version using this method, because I don't know what future versions will be.  
2013-06-12

---

That's fine. That's exactly the behavior we want. For example, System.Runtime didn't ship in 4.0, but did in 4.5. We still want a binding redirect generated for it in 4.0, but not for 4.5.  
2013-06-13

---

I followed the exact same steps above, but there's no binding redirect added to the Console Application. It's only added to the __Portable Library project__. Is that the bug?  
2013-06-13

---

The binding redirects added to the Portable Library project seems to come from the Microsoft.Bcl package itself (from the content folder's app.config.transform file). this looks like a non-bug.
2013-06-13

  
I'm chasing up the repro with Eric St. John. He walked through the code and figured out where it was broken.

It's the not the app.config.tranform, notice how the net45 content is empty, and hence no transforms. We also marked our transforms with a special marker that indicates that we added the redirects . The binding redirects we were seeing were not coming from us.  
2013-06-13

---

Are you seeing the binding redirects added to the Console Application or the Portable Library? I don't see binding redirect added to Console Application, only the Portable Library.  
2013-06-13

---

Yes I'm talking about the ConsoleApplication. The binding redirects in the portable library project are expected, and do not affect runtime behavior (as the app.config is ignored and not copied to the app project), and hence can't cause an application to crash.

I've found another repro (NuGet has really weird logic around when it decides to add binding redirects so it was hard to find a repro).

The repro is instead of using the Microsoft.Bcl package, install the Microsoft.Net.Http, 2.2.3-beta package. Make sure you are targeting __4.5__ from the ConsoleApplication and the exact platforms that I called out above for portable.  
2013-06-13

---

Also, the ConsoleApplication must be referencing the portable project before installing the package.  
2013-06-13

---

OK now I can repro  
2013-06-14

---

OK, I've got a fix now. It no longer adds the binding redirect for System.Runtime.dll, but still adds one for System.Net.Http.Primitives. I guess it's expected, right? Please confirm.

```
<assemblyBinding xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v1">
<dependentAssembly>
<assemblyIdentity name="System.Net.Http.Primitives" publicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" culture="neutral" />
<bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-4.2.3.0" newVersion="4.2.3.0" />
</dependentAssembly>
</assemblyBinding>
```  
2013-06-14

---


Yes that's correct. System.Net.Http.Primitives does not exist in the framework.  
2013-06-14

---

Fixed in changeset b8d515f6341193b970d2a9d837e580e762d2eb71  
2013-06-19

---

i get the same issue with my test project still, runtime being added... if i comment this out the tests run fine... if not i get exceptions thrown from json.net  
2013-08-09

---

(or i can change the version up to 4.0.0.0 or something and it works)  
2013-08-09

2013-06-13

  
I'm chasing up the repro with Eric St. John. He walked through the code and figured out where it was broken.

It's the not the app.config.tranform, notice how the net45 content is empty, and hence no transforms. We also marked our transforms with a special marker that indicates that we added the redirects . The binding redirects we were seeing were not coming from us.  
2013-06-13

---

Are you seeing the binding redirects added to the Console Application or the Portable Library? I don't see binding redirect added to Console Application, only the Portable Library.  
2013-06-13

---

Yes I'm talking about the ConsoleApplication. The binding redirects in the portable library project are expected, and do not affect runtime behavior (as the app.config is ignored and not copied to the app project), and hence can't cause an application to crash.

I've found another repro (NuGet has really weird logic around when it decides to add binding redirects so it was hard to find a repro).

The repro is instead of using the Microsoft.Bcl package, install the Microsoft.Net.Http, 2.2.3-beta package. Make sure you are targeting __4.5__ from the ConsoleApplication and the exact platforms that I called out above for portable.  
2013-06-13

---

Also, the ConsoleApplication must be referencing the portable project before installing the package.  
2013-06-13

---

OK now I can repro  
2013-06-14

---

OK, I've got a fix now. It no longer adds the binding redirect for System.Runtime.dll, but still adds one for System.Net.Http.Primitives. I guess it's expected, right? Please confirm.

```
<assemblyBinding xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v1">
<dependentAssembly>
<assemblyIdentity name="System.Net.Http.Primitives" publicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" culture="neutral" />
<bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-4.2.3.0" newVersion="4.2.3.0" />
</dependentAssembly>
</assemblyBinding>
```  
2013-06-14

---


Yes that's correct. System.Net.Http.Primitives does not exist in the framework.  
2013-06-14

---

Fixed in changeset b8d515f6341193b970d2a9d837e580e762d2eb71  
2013-06-19

i get the same issue with my test project still, runtime being added... if i comment this out the tests run fine... if not i get exceptions thrown from json.net

(or i can change the version up to 4.0.0.0 or something and it works)
